sdo:itemDesc.dc:title: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated July 15, 1894
sdo:itemDesc.dc:description: Harden agrees in principle to Schenker’s publishing elsewhere some material on which Harden had some claim; he advises Schenker that he has no following among the audience of Die Neue Revue; he has heard nothing from Brahms or Rosenthal about contributing something about Bülow to Die Zukunft.
sdo:itemDesc.dc:subject: Harden, Maximilian; Schenker, Heinrich; Neue Revue; Rosenthal, Moriz; Brahms

tei:p.tei:hi: Handwritten postcard from Harden to Schenker, dated July 15, 1894

tei:transcription.tei:p: {recto} [preprinted form with handwritten address information] Deutsche Reichspost Postkarte
An [/] Herrn Dr. H. Schenker in Kautzen [indecipherable symbols] / Oesterreich Wohnung [intentionally left blank]

im Prinzip bin ich durchaus einverstanden. Natürlich muß ich von Fall zu Fall ein Urtheil vorbehalten. Die Neue Revue The Neue Revue was a literary magazine in Vienna, in which Schenker had by this time already published several articles. ist ja gewiß schön, aber da haben Sie kein Publikum, u. das ist auch nicht ganz unwichtig. This message seems to indicate that Schenker had asked Harden for his approval in regard to publishing something in Vienna on which Harden presumably had some claim.

Rosenthal Click on Moriz Rosenthal, student of Karol Mikuli (of whom Schenker had been a pupil, too), and authentic interpreter of Chopin. Harden is hoping that either Brahms or Rosenthal or both will contribute something on Bülow to Die Zukunft, and he is using Schenker as a go-between. See OJ 11/42, [14] and [15]. u. Brahms tacent.

To Dr. H. Schenker in Kautzen [indecipherable symbols] / Austria Address [intentionally left blank]

In principle, I am in complete agreement. Naturally, I have to reserve judgment from case to case. Die Neue Revue| is well and good, but you have no public there, and that is not an entirely trivial matter.
Rosenthal and Brahms tacent [are not responding].
